content:
er 16, 2015
												Door Kickers is a solid game and you might enjoy it (the crushing majority does, as it seems). But for me personally, it was a disappointment. I was really hyped about this game according to the trailers, there was no demo, and the game didn't live up to my expectations.I expected this to be more arcade-like, instead it's more of a planning/puzzle game. That wouldn't be a problem, but I don't like how it's implemented. There are basically two modes you can operate in: full-ahead planning or realtime mode.Full-ahead planning In full-ahead planning, you try to plan the whole operation (or most of it) in advance, and then just hit play and watch the action. It takes a long time, but if it works out, it is satisfactory. The problems are clunky controls and a lot of important stuff missing. Basic things like "look around the whole room in 360° angle and shoot all enemies then go on" are impossible. Instead you can look in one direction, then move a short distance, then look into different direction, then move a short distance, then look into other direction, ... until you cover the whole room. Even if your soldier encounters an enemy, he's happy to follow all the other orders including looking into a completely different direction, turning back to his enemy (what?!). So you need to use "thumb up" mark after every single move to make sure he actually kills the enemy before going away. That gets tiring quickly. A basic AI for your soldiers would be nice, but it's not there, you have to micromanage everything. So the soldier goes according to the plan even if there's a shootout 3 meters away from him. The soldier doesn't automatically take cover even though there's a cover spot half a meter away from him. People might argue this game is about micromanaging. Well, OK (I didn't expect that), but you can hardly do that in full-ahead planning, because enemy positions are random. And the developers give you no means to intelligently react to enemy encounters, neither in planning mode nor when executing the action (see the point below). Editing the plan in the middle is impossible. You have just spent 10 minutes carefully planning everything, and then you figure out that in the very second room you forgot to check the closet. You want to tweak the plan a bit. But guess what - you have to delete the whole plan after the second room, do the adjustments, and then re-create it again from scratch from that point forward. There's no way to edit the prepared plan in the middle. This is so glaring overlook then I can't explain it - for me, this was a showstopper for planning the action ahead. It also applies to real-time modifications to the plan (when you already started executing the actions) - no way to do that, it will destroy the rest of your plan. Say goodbye to intelligently reacting to unexpected events. Synchronizing actions from multiple soldiers is a major PITA. Something as basic as waiting for a flash bang to explode is not implemented. The soldier who threw the flash bang waits a bit (it seems), but the others do not. If you do not throw it through a door but around a corner, no one waits. So you need to do manual synchronization using ABCD codes. A lot of manual chore. If you have two soldiers, one with a shield, you get the obvious idea - one can go in front, shielding them, and the second behind him, shooting from the cover when he sees enemies. But no, there's no way to instruct them to go as a group.Realtime mode In realtime mode (well, almost real time, you usually plan just a few steps ahead and then unpause it), you need to micromanage everything, but at least everything works exactly as you intended - soldiers are properly synchronized, they don't rush into rooms before flashbangs explode, etc. However, if anything goes wrong and you need to restart the mission, it's an immense chore instructing them through all the rooms again, and again, and again. You can't save and reuse parts of previous plans. You can't toggle them to semi-AI mode and make them a bit smarter. So instead of spending a lot of time planning, you spend a lot of time redoing all your previous realtime instructions many times over. The realtime mode pains could be save by allowing the player to do "snapshots" - quicksaves and quickloads, but that's not there. Or perhaps offering to save and recall short-time plans for individual rooms, but that's not there either.So, in summary, I felt that I'm either frustrated by inadequate controls in full-ahead planning mode, or that I'm repeating the same short-time realtime plans over and over again, until I finally finished the level. I couldn't enjoy it.There are some technical issues as well, which annoyed me: Multimedia keys don't work, unless you switch to Steam overlay. Alt+tab doesn't work, unless you switch to Steam overlay. But then it glitches, and even though you are switched to other applications, Door Kickers are still displayed on top of them (so you can't see what you're doing). On top of that, you can't switch back to DK. That basically means you must try to kill the game blindly, or restart the computer, just because of using Alt+Tab (and of course you'll lose all unsaved progress). I'm using GNOME as a desktop environment, might be an issue specific to that.Aside from the technical issues, I like sound effects of this game, music is OK, but I don't like the graphics. First, the absolutely top down perspective doesn't look good, just a bit of isometric view would work much better. Second, the graphics are ugly and blurry, and the texture quality (or artwork quality, however you want to call that) is low. I have correct resolution set, but the whole game looks upscaled and far from crystal clear as I expected.

content:
er 21, 2015
												Now before I go into my review I want to make one thing clear. I love this game. It is a very cool experience for those looking for a tactical strategy challenge of commanding a swat team breaching a building. However, there are just a few things that ruin the experience for me in some cases.First: The AIThe biggest problem that I have with the enemy AI is that they constantly open doors and just run out of them without and moments thought instead of posting up and keeping there guns trained on a door as they should be doing. Watching my guys mow down half of the enemy on one level just because they kept moving down a narrow hallway instead of fortifying themselves really broke my immersion.Second: Lack of Surrender OptionIf I was playing a military game, I wouldn't have a problem with my troops just gunning down unsuspecting enemies, and inspite of what people might think, SWAT team members are NOT allowed to open fire first unless they give proper warning and demand surrender from the enemy. The fact that this doesn't happen, and for a game that I assume is supposed to be simulating SWAT team breaches, really is disappointing when you compare it to something like SWAT 4 which this game seems to emulate from a strategic standpoint.Third: IrratationNow while some people may get the joy of going through a level for an hour trying to create the perfect plan, that isn't me. I'm the kind of guy who likes to do a level only a few times and not have to rely on trial and error mechanics to complete a level. And when I do complete one I don't feel sastisfaction at all.Fourth: ProgressionTo be fair, I'm not sure what progression system I would have chosen for this game, but I don't know if a star system like on mobiles games would have been the route I went. Really makes grinding extremely annoying. Plus I end up just not using most of the weapons and only go for the ones that are the best in the game.Fifth: Hostage Death = RestartThis is probably this most frustrating aspect of this game. I'm not sure what real life SWAT would consider a hostage being killed a failure, but being forced to restart the entire level just because one hostage out of like 12 gets killed is overly punishing. Especially if you consider that the SAS (I know its not SWAT but still) raid on the Iranian Embassy was considered a success even though a hostage was killed in the siege.Sixth: PriceFor a game that is $20, it just doesn't feel like it is worth $20 in the end. (I would recommend this game for $5 when it goes on sale but no more) DISAVOWED. $5 definitely pick this up, $10 sure, $15 eh pushing it but would still recommend, $20 no (at least for me). Some people might think this game is worth $20, which is perfectly fine if they believe so, but for me personally $15 would probably be a better base price tag.Overall, its a great concept and a good game, but it needs to lower its price and work on some of its flaws before I can change my review to positive.

er 28, 2015
Door Kickers - 8.5/10 Door Kickers is an addicting and challenging game, that hooked me from the first level. Much like Hotline Miami, the theme of a SWAT team making dangerous and daring rescue attempts is merely a cover up for Door Kickers' core puzzle like mechanics. The awesome feeling of pulling off a succsessful three star rescue attempt, after carefully planning down to the micro level each individual action of our members is second to none.The game presents you with several ways to access missions and earn currency (currency allows you to purchase different weapons and gear). Playing missions in each of the campaigns (there are currently 6 campaigns) Playing each of the over 100 standalone missions Downloading maps from the workshop (These do not get you currency) Making your own maps (These do not get you currency)The unlockable gear allows you to customise each opertive and in the later game it often makes sense to give each of your opperative a weapoin tailored to what they will have to do. Alongside this, there are also 5 classes, Pointman, Assaulter, Breacher, Stealth and Shield. They each have unique weapons and some shared weapons, as well as unique equipment.There is lots of good things to say about Door Kickers, but there are also a few issue at the moment. You are not able to reshape the path of an opperative without getting rid of all the rest of the path. The unlock system can be tedious at times and it can sometimes feel like a grind. Sometimes when you spend a long time creating a plan in order to get three stars, and then you have to quit the game or you feel like changing levels. There is no way to save your plan so you have to remake it when you come back.Overall door kickers is a great game that will easily last you 20 hours, and most likely even more. It is a particullarly good game to just pick up and play for short ammount of time, once you have unlocked a few of the weapons. BUY IT!

Summary: The game is awesome & full of tactical challenges.I've got this game in a bundle sale few months back, that's why it was untouched before. Recently I saw the announcement of the sequel so I though let's complete the first game. The game is really well made. Although it is top-down perspective but still graphical details are quite good. The game is challenging and it takes quite a precision planning to get 3 stars.Game play is very simple to learn but hard to master. You'll be presented with a map with few goons (default game comes with 6 campaigns and 75+ standalone maps), some time bomb or hostage or evidences (campaign only). You have to choose 2 or 4 or 8 soldiers and deploy in different location throughout the maps. Locations are pre-defined. Then you have to invade the map and kill the goons or capture the evidences or stop the bomb timer or rescue hostages. However, it requires precision timing and path / action assignment to coordinated attacks so that your soldiers don’t get injured (or killed). In hostage rescue situation, you’ll have to do it multiple times because you’ll die a lot or a goon has killed a hostage (strictly not allowed). This part is really challenging for softcore gamer like me.If I want to give point to this game, I’d give 8 out of 10. One of the best indie game in recent time. A must-have title.PS: This game has mod support; Steam workshop has lots of community created maps for more enjoyment.

If you like throwing bangs, slicing pies, T-zoning, stacking and generally going HAM; do yourself a favor and pick it up.

er 11, 2014
												Fantastic game. Highly recommended. Harkens back to Rainbow Six (as you'll constantly read). Focusing on this game, however, it has solid gameplay mechanics. And is fair in it's execution. I did run in to one level that I couldn’t figure out but that was one level out of hundreds. And yes, this game has 100s of prebuilt scenarios. Also, it has a random mission generator. You get your money's worth and it's fun. There is not too much story -- actually, no story is fair to note but there is are 3 different "campaigns" that you can go through. Also the aforementioned 100s of missions and then the mission generator. So, again, a ton of content to be had. I don't have many complaints with the game. I suppose I wish it explained some the gear a bit better but for the most part you figure it out. To the best of my knowledge, a good portion of items are interchangeable. I could be wrong, who knows... Strongly recommended. Just buy it. Don't wait for a sale or anything silly. If you enjoy rainbow six (the planning phase, I should mention) and you like strat games, just buy it. It's an indie; support these guys and they can then bring out more awesome games.  The game is well optimized. It runs on my older laptops with ease as far as I can tell. No performance concerns to note.

content:
r 6, 2014
												UPDATE TO THE UPDATE: I've just passed 100 hours in the game. Still pretty much a lot of fun. The developers have announced they are working on new updates expected before the end of the year to include an enhanced editor and more gameplay modes. So even if you aren't interested right now, put it on your wishlist and it might be on an upcoming Steam Sale.UPDATE: I'm posting a short update to this review. I've just passed eighty(80) hours in the game. The developers have released two updates, adding some new features and fixing some small bugs. The Steam Workshop community is very actively supporting the game (I have several mods there myself). Still highly recommended.ORIGINAL REVIEW:If you are at all interested in the subject you should definitely give it a look. The game is already well supported by the community and the Steam Workshop has some excellent mods, weapons and levels already. It's the old SWAT or Rainbow Six from a top down, 2D perspective that puts more emphasis on planning than quick reactions. Check out some of the Let's Play videos out there, or some mission video captures posted on my YouTube channel for more information.Now that it is in release, there are even more interesting features, the major ones being multistory buildings and drug busts where you have to race to seize the evidence before the bad guys dispose of it. Three campaigns have been added, which are a series of linked missions (also with some branched, optional missions) where you are limited to your existing roster. Without giving away any spoilers, there are a couple of really large maps set on a waterfront and a train station that combine long sight distances, dangerous approaches and unusual rooms and buildings. The game is pretty much bug free due to the long alpha period, with only a couple of minor items that have to be addressed. There is an excellent level editor that works pretty well, the only really awkward part being the current need to edit the background image (which is the floor or ground of the map) outside of the editor, should you want one that isn't the default grey warehouse floor. The developers have stated that they intend to add that background editing ability into the in-game editor. Also of note is the excellent Mission Generator. You select the size of the level and the amount of opposition and the game generates a random seed. Then you select either "KillHouse" (for a training map) or "House" (for a real world map) and the game generates a mission using one of the maps in the game. The mission could be just to eliminate hostiles, or escort a VIP, or run a drug bust, or rescue hostages. It's a real challenge because it's newly generated. Overall this is an excellent value for the price; three campaigns, 80 official missions (once you enable the two new missions via the Mods interface), a Mission Generator and tons of mods already in the Workshop. Highly Recommended.

content:
6, 2016
												I had seen videos of Doorkickers before receiving it in a bundle.  I have played games such as Frozen Synapse and Jagged Alliance 2, and found the tactical genre to be a bit of a mixed bag.  So when I saw videos of Doorkickers, I didn't think much of it.  SInce it came with a bundle of other games I liked, I gave Doorkickers a shot.And it was far more enjoyable than trailers and gameplay videos could get across.The joy of Doorckickers is primarily the tactical system.  From movement to breaching to cover and co-ordination, you have to think about them all, and the game lets you control it in a simple and easy to use interface.  The method of control is also flexible: you can plan every move in advance and let the scenario play out, or you can pause at any time to alter the gameplan when things go sideways.  Changes can be made in real-time as well.  The end result of all of this control and flexibility is a deep tactical planning stage followed by a typically short but explosive rush of action.Each mission stage is a layout of a building, structure, or outdoor location.  Warehouses, beach villas, parking garages, multi-story luxury apartments, and more... with Steam Workshop and a built-in editor, the variety in size, complexity, and tactical options are impressive.  You can play one off missions or dive into multi-mission campaigns where injury and death are long-term inhibiting factors.  A hardcore ironman mode is available to prevent repeated attempts at a mission to save key teammates from injury or death.Most missions have multiple tactical approaches based on which officers and gear you use.  Some missions are somewhat linear and can be approached methodically, while others usually turn into controlled chaos that you pray doesn't get you killed.  There is an element of RNG to shot accuracy, stopping power, and enemy numbers, but solid tactical choices can be made to deal with it.The squad you control is manned by officers you can customize in name, callsign, appearance, and gear.  Skill perks are squad training that all officers get the benefit of.  Roles include pointman, assaulter, breacher, stealth, and shield.  Each fills a vital part of the tactics, and they feel useful in their dominant environments.  When the mission changes, you can change up all gear and role assignments.Weapons range from the ubiquitous handgun, SMGs and carbines, shotguns, and non-lethals.  The variety of weaponry is sufficient, and a slew can be added with the Workshop.  Gear includes various armors, tactical grenades, cameras, and breaching devices.  It's fun to switch up loadouts, but there isn't too much here to overload the player with inventory management.There are bonuses in each mission to encourage different playstyles.  Lone wolf tasks you with clearing a mission with one officer, which casn be incredibly difficult.  One award is given for playing entirel in realtime with no pauses.  Lastly, an award can be earned for planning an entire breach and clear in advance, hitting play, and succeeding with no pauses or changes to the gameplan.  This last award is the most satisfying of all, and when 5-10 minutes of planning leads to a flawless execution of a 3-4 minute mission... the exhileration is real.  You can also save replays within the game, or export the replay to a video file to share and cherish always.Bottom line is that this game is a tactical dream that can be played for short bursts or full-auto for hours.  The variety and depth provide a solid amount of content.  Mods extend the life of the game and add all sorts of new weapons, gear, and interface alternatives.If your satisfaction is partly predicated on price, I would wager $10 to be wholly worthwhile.  That's 50% off the standard price, which might be steep for most.  Luckily, the game has been around a while and sales on this title are frequent.So gear up and get tactical!  It's time to sweep this hot spot like an efficient wave of justice.

content:
6, 2015
												Door kickers is Awesome!Your OfficersYou can have a total of 10 officers. You will give each officer a class which you can change at any time before a mission starts. There are 5 classes total, 4 to unlock. You start with Pointman and unlock Assaulter, Shield, Breacher and finally Stealth. You then customize each officers class specific gear.Officer Ranking and Squad RankingEach officer has his or her own rank which increases as they complete missions successfully. Their skill level increases with rank. As your officers rank up so does your overall squad rank. DoctrineEach time your squad rank increases you gain a doctrine point. These points are spent on pistol skills, long gun skills and shotgun skills. These skills are passive and improve every officer regardless of their rank.DeathYour officers can die permanently and will be replaced with rookie officers if you choose to continue after a  successful mission. If you restart the mission you will still have that said officer for consecutive attempts.Missions and GearEach mission has a 3 star rating system. Each star awarded is currency to unlock gear. Gear is unlocked for the entire squad once you spend the stars. There are single missions, campaign missions and a mission generator for random missions. There is also the mission editor and steam workshop. You can plan a mission from beginning to end before you start. You can also pause the game anytime to plan as you go. If you are really brave you don't have to pause at all. It is very rewarding to watch your officers execute a perfect plan. You can even save replays and export videos in game. ConclusionIt takes 10 minutes to plan a mission and anywhere from 5 seconds to 2 minutes to execute the takedowns. This game could probably be used as a training tool if given to the right people. Door kickers is all about tacticle planning and strategy. Very fun game to play! Easily worth the full price but if you see it on sale don't hesitate to pick this one up.

8, 2016
												Door Kickers was a huge surprise for me. A friend gifted me a copy and I have to say Door Kickers is like drugs, once it gets a hold of you you just don't want to stop playing. Door Kickers has you managing a SWAT team with upgradeable skills and equipment. During the missions there are a variety of objectives such as collecting evidence, defusing bombs, saving hostages, or just eliminating hostiles. You set up your team at the beginning of the mission and then plan out what they are going to do, once you press play the SWAT team runs into action performing all teh actions you set before hand. Now in Door Kickers you can watch your plan play out on screen, hoping for the best and restart if something goes awry, however if you are not worried about getting a "perfect plan" you can pause and modify your actions for your team at any time! There are a few different options when it comes to mission modes. You have the single missions, for quick play, you have the mission generator that lets you generate missions based on a few different parameters, and then you have the campaigns. There are a good handful of playable campaigns each with a variety of challenges and difficulties. If you couple that with the tons of different equipment and classes each SWAT member can have you are talking tons of gameplay and variation! If it did not sound like it could be any better Door Kickers also has mod and Steam workshop support! If any of the above sounds interesting I urge you to check out Door Kickers, or even the upcoming Door Kickers 2!

content:
2, 2014
https://libertariangaming.org/?p=1465 <better version of my review in the link behind!Doorkickers is an indie RTS/Puzzle game which involves you leading a SWAT team through missions. I've been following this game since late Alpha and have enjoyed it since it's early form. The gameplay is quite simple, but is hard to master. Basically you give your team check points to go to through the mission area. You tell them where to go, where to face, what to use and so on. It's somewhat similar to the mission planning of the old Rainbow Six games but now in live action, with a live pause available. The game features five classes that your officers can pick from. Pointman, Assaulter, Breacher, Stealth and Shield. The Pointman is the fastest through the door, but only wields a handgun. The Assaulter packs either an SMG or an assault rifle and is best at ranged gun fights. Breachers wield shotguns and can blow doorlocks off. Stealth wield silenced weapons and move quieter. Shield men wield large shields that stop bullets. In my opinion, most of the classes are useful, but I don't really use the shields as they are slow, and are doomed if they are flanked.There is about 80 single missions, 3 campaigns, a random mission generator and an simple editor so there is a lot of content on offer. The campaigns aren't very story driven, at all. There isn't a paragraph describing any story. I'm not saying it ruins the experience but it would have been nice to have that. Officers do take injuries during missions and can die, but this only really affects the campaign. The campaigns are quite short, but entertaining, and are worth replaying for experience points and stars (explained later). Although this game is mainly about planning, there is a bit of luck involved. I'd say it's 9/10 planning and 1/10 luck. Just know that ♥♥♥♥ poor planning leads to ♥♥♥♥ poor performance. One great thing about this game, is you can wing it, or plan the whole mission out (which gives a bonus in EXP).You unfortunately do have to unlock equipment during the game. Troopers level up during missions, and your entire squad levels up as well. Leveling troopers grants them better speed with shooting and using tools and accuracy. Leveling the squad grants doctrine points which grant all members improved abilities such as accuracy boosts, and one shot door breaching. It also gives access to more classes, as you only start with pointmen.Another thing worth noting is that you have to unlock weapons, by acquiring stars during missions. You get one for completing, one for having all troopers alive and one for beating it under time. It can be challenging getting all 3 stars on some missions but the rewards are worth it.One complaint I will make is that you have to erase all of your checkpoints ahead of a checkpoint if you want to make changes. This can make it more time consuming to change plans. I also find that sometimes I accidentally erase points which can be very frustrating.Another issue is the new story mechanic. Some missions have multiple levels but to be honest changing between them is quite awkward in my opinion and I feel the game would be better without them. My other complaint is that this game doesn't have a solid tutorial. Fortunately you can practice all you like on the single missions without an issue. The graphics of this game are quite simple, but I honestly think it's unfair to expect better from a 3 man indie team considering the scale of this game, and it's certainly better looking than a Unity engine game and to be honest the menu background looks great.Doorkickers has been my first adventure into PC indie gaming, and easily the best. A small, and passionate team who actually listen to the players, and use the advice to develop a competent and entertaining game that was realistically achievable. I'd give Doorkickers a 9/10.

content:
ry 16, 2015
												This is a great game, and it doesn't have a difficult learning curve to the play style.  First, you take over a SWAT team that consists of ten members with varying attributes in marksmanship, assault shooting(close quarters), and field skills(a skill that speeds up the ability to disarm bombs for instance).Since the game is in the top down mode, you are able to script out the directions you want your team members to move, provide covering fire, which doors to breach etc...  This is done before the match, and if you realize you made a mistake during the fight, you're able to pause, and re-adjust your routes, and covering fire; or you can make adjustments in real time.  As I said earlier, it's not a difficult learning curve, once you realize it's about applying covering fire for teams moving in open areas, or stacking alongside a room you're about to throw a flash bang in.  There is limitless possibilities you can create within the scenarios.The game offers 80 missions(and often, when updates happen, more missions appear).  You can also create your own quick missions with varying styles.  Which means you can go in just to kill the enemies, capture and arrest individuals without lethal harm, disarm bombs and rescue hostages.  The game offers 5 campaigns at the time of this review, and they each have an additional 5-6 missions of varying difficulty.  This is not to forget that Steam Workshop is enabled for this game, and you're honestly left with so many choices that just about everyone can find something they're comfortable with(ie: you can apply mods for military type actions, with military weapons , or extra police type actions for instance).The game progresses your characters by the number of missions that they accomplish, and the skills being applied are done for you.  It's up to you, and the mission to decide which of your team members gets placed in the action(for instance if you're disarming a bomb, you'll want someone with high field skills).  You'll also get experience to level up, which then you can unlock perks from a tree of skills to enhance skills with firearms(pistols, shotguns and rifles/carbines).  The game unlocks after certain levels as you can get different character sets, like breachers(shotguns), stealth(silenced weapons and movement), and using police shields to add extra defense to your team members.  Yet there is even more, you gain stars by completing missions(1 to 3 stars depending on what conditions are met), which the stars can be turned into buying upgraded weapons, body armor, accessories(tazer, breaching kit for example.  You basically have full control on what your team needs to complete the mission.This game doesn't have too many flaws(at least when I've played), and the developers are still really active in producing content for the game.  What I do find enjoyable about this game is that it feels satisfying every time I play.  I don't feel like I have to commit 2 to 3 hours a day to enjoy the game.  I can honestly play a single mission, or 30 minutes and I won't feel disappointed in what I've accomplished; and certainly there is enough it do in this game to have you lose track of time and play hours at a time if you wish.  I highly recommend this game if you enjoy a tactical game where you're able to do all the planning and adjusting real time.  You won't be disappointed.10/10

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
y 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								Let me start by saying that I'm just a casual gamer that's into a variety of games, and had never heard of these developers (or really any indie devs!) before this game. I don't benefit at all by giving this a positive review, except perhaps by helping to share this great game and thus contribute indirectly to the sales and community - possibly allowing the devs to make it even better!Door Kickers is a Fantastic Game!! -- One of the best I've ever played, and there's still lots more to come! Door Kickers offers an enjoyable, realistic and informative peek into the world of tactical response police and special forces that is very secretive and usually hard to find (portrayed even semi-accurately at least) in the entertainment world. In a simple, fun, and effective way it showcases realistic tactics, weaponry, gadgets, radio chatter and movements in a variety of hostage, bomb defusal, room clearing and even tubular assault scenarios. Door Kickers is particularly enjoyable if you're into Police or Military Tactical Response/SWAT or Special Forces, but even if you're not, it's still an amazing and rewarding tactical game that enables you to think, plan and execute different strategies in a variety of different scenarios. It's NOT an exceedingly difficult game by any means, but there is plenty of room for perfectionist work if you so desire. Although the trailers play at full speed, there is a tactical pause feature that lets you think, plan and execute your strategies as fast or slow as you want. Would recommend Door Kickers to everyone! Lots of very cool new stuff is promised in the near future, such as Snipers, Ballistic Shields, Tazers, and a Campaign (in addition to the dozens of single missions currently available). The updates have been released very regularly so far - the devs obviously care about the game and have already implemented alot of suggestions from the community!   In short, you should get it!  You won't regret buying this game!    11/10!

content:
er 1, 2014
												Door Kickers is a pause and plan RTS with a focus on high energy, high impact tactical gunfights.  You normally control a team of 2-8 SWAT personnel and are charged with eliminating tangoes, defusing bombs, rescuing hostages and all sorts of other goodness.  The planning is intuitive & easy to implement.  It can be done entirely through mouse commands or by using the keyboard to trigger go codes.  Gameplay is fast and lethal - your SWAT wear body armor, but that doesn't mean they won't go down if someone empties a MAC-10 at them or if they step out in front of a shotgun.  As a result, you're constantly planning how best to win the fight before your man is ever in view - distracting the enemies by popping a trooper into view and then flanking them, stunning them with flashbang grenades or whatever other fiendish tricks you manage to pull off.  Enemy A.I. varies from cautious (hunker down and wait) to aggressive (investigate gunfire/other loud sounds) and changes between playings.  Most of the more complex scenarios offer several possible enemy set ups, deemphasizing puzzle-based planning and providing a more organic experience (is that room to the left clear or can it be safely ignored?).  The enemies carry a full range of weapons and can even load up on heavy body armor - there are an unrealistically large number of tangos, but this yields a more satisfying experience and you'll find yourself going along with it.Moreover, I have been playing Door Kickers since the alpha and, with each new iteration, the game has continued to grow and evole.  The dedication of Killhouse Games to delivering the best product possible has been something to behold and I can say that from personal experience they are very receptive to feedback from the community.   They have worked hard to pack a lot of value into the package - at present there are over seventy single player maps, plus three campaigns, a random scenario generator and an editor to enable users to design their own maps.  The game itself offers a wide variety of experiences, from simple missions that can be knocked out in a few minutes (when you're just looking for a quick release during downtime) to large, complex hostage rescues which require both planning and precision to pull off.In short, this is one of the best computer game purchases I have made over the last couple years - if any of the above sounds appealing then I highly recommend picking the game up.

content:
er 19, 2014
												Fantastic game. Worth every penny.If you have played any of the previous SWAT or Rainbow Six games, you can expect a similar strategic style, albeit in a top down isometric view. It's one of those easy to learn, hard to master type games, where you will constantly perfect strategies and re-run missions to achieve 3-star ratings. The game rewards your hard work with unlockables, specifically new guns and gadgets. There is also a level up system, similar to that of the XCOM series, where specific officers will improve their abilities as they are involved in missions. There is a mixture of both campaigns and time-trial based single missions and already an abundance of content.The game already has a vibrant modding scene, which is great because this game lends itself to the creation of new maps and guns. It already feels like there is far too much to do in it.The game is also extremely polished. There are a couple of small bugs here and there, but it's highly unlikely you will encounter anything game-breaking.Highly recommended!

												This is one of the best tatical games I have played in a long time. While I am still figuring out the full logistics of the game, it has been so fun, that a review was in order. content:
0, 2014
Early Access Review
								Door Kickers adds a great level of polish and accessibility to a hardcore tactical game. It plays quite similarly to Frozen Synapse, or the planning phase from old-school Rainbow 6, but your troopers are extremely easy to control and manage. You can either try to develop the perfect plan from the get-go, or pause the action and modify your plan on-the-fly as you react to enemy movement. Speaking of the enemy, the AI in this game is fantastic. The enemy AI will move around the map, patrol, react to sound and fighting, and surprise the hell out of you by flanking your men that you thought were perfectly surrounded in cover. Add to this a potent blend of customization, and wide range of tactical options at your disposal (you can play as a silent death squad, with all recon troops, or with a band of door-breaching shotgun-wielding fighters, or anything in between).

content:
1, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is one of the most refeshing takes on tactical shooters I've played in the past few years. Everything in this game is simple to allow just about anyone to pick it up and play, yet still allows an immense sense of depth and tactics. I'm a huge miltary nerd when it comes to CQC tactics, needless to say I couldnt checkout fast enough when I figured out what this game actually was. It cures that tactical itch that hasen't been touched since the early Rainbow Six / Ghost recon days. Yeah it's THAT good. This game is an unforgiving monster, but at the same time is as sweet as candy when you know what your doing. Setting up your entire plan in one step, then watching all your men carry them out with precision... that's something that never fails to bring a smile to my face. I jumped on the bandwagon pretty early, and every alpha that gets released I find myself saying "How did I live without this?" This game started out solid, and improves by leaps and bounds with every alpha released. The Devs. are also a great group of guys, always listining to the fans for feedback and future ideas. Two thumbs up to all of you at Killhouse, you guys are freaking awesome!

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 10
												Doorkickers is TOTALLY COMPELLING. You maneuver your team (often just two operatives in the early missions) through a space, using a waypoint order system - and you can pause at any time to issue new orders or completely change your plan. And every map has slightly randomized enemy placement, so you can't just learn the board and precisely plan for it; one run thru will go wonderfully, but on a second try for more points, both operatives will be killed when the enemy placement changes just a bit. So it becomes not about learning the maps, but learning good tactical discipline, regardless of the map. And enemies are smart; I've been snuck up on and ambushed. By going back through the early missions several times with untested, rookie operatives I was able to unlock the Assaulter class quite quickly - what has been described as a 'grind' looks a lot more like skill refinement, to me. When I got to a campaign mission and was completely owned - repeatedly - on the second map, I realized my command of my abilities was quite lacking, and went back to polish up. I've also been watching some enjoyably brief Let's Plays (by RedatMath) and seeing I haven't even used certain tools in my early arsenal, like the camera wand or breaching charges. So complaints of having to grind for simple tools don't resonate with me - the game feels like it's asking me to gain mastery with my starting toolset before widening it. Overall, I'm finding it a very enjoyable tactical hole to climb inside; there's always another way to handle a room, another challenge from a room with too many entrances, and another door that needs to be viciously kicked and stormed through. 10/10 would run in and get shot again.

content:
er 31, 2015
												Honestly I love this game, I've own this game for about a couple days now, and I've already wasted 11 hours into it.I'm going to base this game on 3 categories: Price, A.I., Replayability1st the price 10/10. Well to be honest when I had first seen this game I thought it was a fairly simple game that would be worth, at max $5, but then I looked further into it, and for the amount of content this game offers $20 is more than a fair price. This game offers not only 6 seperate campaigns (With their own lengths and difficulties) 70+ missions (seperate from the campaigns) steam workshop availibility, but also your own map creator. Now honestly how many other games give you this much content for just $202nd the A.I 8/10. The A.I. could use some improvement I will admit, but people saying that the A.I. doesn't fortify in a room are wrong, the A.I. do fortify in rooms, for example on the single player mission Cartel Beach Party (Unfortunately the chief wasn't invited and was very displeased about it, so he had told a small handful of the best troopers to go in there and end the party.) the A.I. do fortify, how they fortify I will not tell, you'll have to find that out on your own. There a multitidue of other misisons the A.I. fortify on, but this mission is the best example (at least to my knowledge)3rd replayability 10/10. This game is all about replayability, there is tons of ways you could go about beating every mission, want to go full stealth ops on every mission? Go ahead! Want to just shotgun the sh!t out of everyone? Be my guest! Want to try and beat every mission with your most well seasoned trooper? Do as you please, no one is stopping you! Other than the multitude of ways you could go about beating every mission you can also challenge yourself by trying to beat your old highscores on every mission. (Or at least getting 3 stars on every mission)

content:
er 17, 2013
Early Access Review
								This is a great game for those of you that enjoyed games like the Swat series, Jagged Alliance, and "Breach & Clear (On Android/iOS systems and or Tactical and strategy enthusist.  This game combines tactical with strategy allowing you to setup your SWAT team by choosing the weaponery, stacking your units on a door to either breach/bang/c2/kick/shoot the door, and sweep the room guns blazing or going stealth. Amazingly the game allows you to pause and coordinate your manuvers. For example if I want my men to look a certain direction when sweeping a room, it allows me to do it with ease. The gameplay is pretty straight foward and easy, it can be tough though, espicially if you don't coordinate wisely. In other words it's very easy to have a man down so be careful. Lastly, the A.I. is pretty good, sometimes they all end up coming to you which can be unrealistic but other times they can be super realistic. Espcially when you have a hostage sceneario. The hostage A.I. are pretty complex too, If you kill the other suspects for every shot the hostage taker hears, he takes a gamble on whether he will kill the hostage, wait, or investiage. If you're LE, Military, or just love being tactical, this is the game for you!

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
11, 2015
												WARNING:Most of my complains here are after the 12 hour mark, but in future content may be added which fixes the issues I have.Doorkickers is a top down SWAT simulater where you control a small team and plan different raids. You have a planning stage for each map where you could take 30 minutes making sure you cover everthingthing, or you can go by the seat of your pants, since you can pause time and give orders in the raid itself. Doorkickers is mostly about planning each mission to perfection, and at the beginning it's great- the maps are small, you can generally plan the whole thing out and make no alterations to that plan and it's wonderfully tense as everyone dies in a few hits. However, after around 12 hours it all falls apart- maps are larger and there are more enemies, so you have to be flexible and this means no more planning for the entire mission, it's more room by room. Gang members get bullet proof vests, high powered weapons and explosives (WHAT?!) so they tend to be massively over powered, and this ruins the balancing that was perfect before.Really, aside from some control issues and not being able to plan for team members dying the beginning of the game was a good 9/10 but after it was watching it slowly die off. I will recommend it for the fun that could be had but it really was disappointing

content:
13, 2015
												This is an amazing real-time strategy game. Not only does it have tons of content (5 classes, 70+ missions plus 5 campaigns with another 38 missions), it requires well-thought out plans to progress. This game makes you feel like a real SWAT commander, just like the old Rainbow Six and SWAT games. I also love how detailed the levels are. But the number 1 reason I love this game is the AI. Most enemies run to cover or hide, like real terrorists would, and as soon as they hear cops, they execute hostages (Which is why you need to be stealthy, just like the SWAT when they rescue people). Then there are operators who stealthily throw grenades through windows before you even see them (smart, huh?). The game may sound really difficult, and it is ( I had a to try a mission full of operators 600+ times! ). Luckily the game has a restart button you can press when somebody dies (unless you are playing iroman, like the hardcore.) My only complaints are some missions favour the AI, and there is one mission I cant get more than 1 star on because sometimes an enemy is outside the map. Overall, this was a great game that i enjoyed, and I look forward to any new games that Kill House may release. Graphics 7/10Gameplay 9.5/10Music 10/10Overall: 9/10

content:
r 24, 2014



YouTube™ Video: MOB Reviews: Door Kickers 

			Views: 688		

			Door Kickers is a top down tactical strategy game on Steam here: http://store.steampowered.com/app/248610/ Join us at Twitter or Facebook if that is your thing: https://twitter.com/TheSocioPsycho...		

Door Kickers is a top down tactical, turn based SWAT-style game.  The game alsoallows for mods, and they provide the tools for player to generate new levels,adding to the already large amount of content the game contains and encouragingreplay-ability.  Each level includes stars to encourage proficient play, as wellas challenges for the missions, which also encourages players to replay levelsto try for better scores.The UI is basic click and drag, as you position your SWAT team members in eachmission to try to immobilize the enemy.  You cannot plan too far ahead, however,as the enemies randomize their patrol routes and pathing.  The gamealso utilizesthe restart function well, so that you can learn from mistakes and correct them.Weapons have a skill set, and individual players have skill sets as well, whichgives the players a chance to customize the game to their preference.  Thedifferent player abilities as well as the variety of weapons and their customi-zation are very well balanced.The abundance of variety in this game take away from any linear feel, as well asthe randomization of the enemies.  The game is very just, and at no time did Ifeel like my time was wasted.  This game does everything that it set out to verywell.  I enjoyed my time playing this game, and can easily recommend it.This is a summary of what I talk about in the video, I am a YT'er not a BloggerThanks for your viewership and support for more videos check click here.http://www.youtube.com/user/SocioPyscho

number of helpful: 16 of 28 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
19, 2016
												I cannot recomment this game in good conscience.  It is a great concept, but its excecution is so flawed that it is often more frustrating than enjoyable!There are a number of bugs/flaws which makes for a frustrating experience.  For one, you cannot delete all the checkpionts, so you find yourself making mistakes and then having to undo your entire plan because a point that you definitely do not want, decides it wants to stay.On top of this, the men do not always listen to your commands.  I have a mission where I have to breach a number of doors and my men surprise me by deciding if and when to throw their flash bangs!  So I went to 80-90% success, only to have this kind of ridiculous mistake happen and have to start all over!Your men are in fact untrained dumbskies!  If, for example, they are told to breach a door, but that door gets opened by the enemy, your men get to that point and sit there like sitting ducks.  So you can have a perfect plan that goes down in flames because a door, which they think they need to breach is already open and they don't know what to do from there.The randomness is a bit too random, sometimes, baddies are just piled into a room, so a perfect plan goes bad because you simply cannot cover everyone.  In real life, thee men do not hang out in three corners of a room waiting for something to happen!There are a lot of missions and content, but they all seem to be the same.  It would have been much better if the missions were progressive, you learning new skills and dealing with intentional situations.  This feels like empty game play that is very redundant.These combined makes the game too frustrating to truly enjoy!

content:
4, 2014
Early Access Review
								Door kickers is great. Its easy to understand but hard to master and the single screen levels are great for killing five mins here and there. The game is about guiding a Armed team of presumably cops through a level capping bad guys, saving hostages and defusing bombs. It’s like a top down version of rainbow six. The levels are varied as are the unit types and the game play is fast yet addictive. You’ll want to get you times as fast as possible while incurring no team deaths again very similar to rainbow six. I also respect the developers of this indie title, they’ve been working hard to continually update the game and the updates are always big deals that add a lot of new content or features. They are also very good at interacting with their consumers and those that bought the game early. It’s jus t anice touch of class that is sometimes lacking. The integration of Steam Workshop is also awesome. In all Doorkickers is awesome and I’ve spent a lot of time with it. I genuinely look forward to the next update as they always do something pretty cool.

content:
y 30, 2015
												If you like tactical games, or even have a passing interested in strategy games, I highly recommend picking this one up. If you are like me and played and loved old school SWAT/Rainbow Six games, then you owe it to yourself to buy this right now.Cons:- A bit pricey compared to other indie games of similar (high) quality- Some difficulty spikes: the progression of difficulty in both campaigns and separate maps could be smoother, though it never feels impossiblePros:- Great music- Amazingly simple yet effective controls- Overall wonderful atmosphere for such simple graphics- Nice sense of progression (even with failed missions) with both individual team member and squad leveling without it entirely revolving around power gained from leveling up- Lots of content, with multiple campaigns, individual maps with rankings, a random mission generator, a mission builder, and plenty more to download on steam workshopMeh:- Sound effects are merely ok- Some odd bugs here and there that take you out of the experience, but aren't game-breaking- Destructible environments would've been niceTLDR: Well worth your time and effort as a strategy gamer.

												They understood everything which makes this kind of game entertaining.You can always finish a mission after tries and retries, but mastering the winning keys is another story. Pick your equipment, position your men, and take decisions always trying to minimize the risks for your men. The "Tacos" AI is pretty good. Some will hide and wait for you, other Tacos will be more agressive, they will lookout from where the sounds are (use this against them).There missions are varied, from the classic "kill everybody", protect a VIP, to recover the drug before it gets destroyed, or disarm a bomb before it explodes. The number of levels is astounding, all with their particularities.If you are good and patient enough, you may prepare your whole plan carefully and just watch your men move on. Or you can play in realtime, or a mix of both. Two very nice approaches.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
12, 2016
												This is probably one of the best tactical games I've ever played.Every mission requires precise planning, a good loadout for the situation, and teamwork. You can't just run in and shoot up the place and win. You must use your squad to execute precise maneuvers in order to complete the objective with minimal SWAT casualties. For example, using a spy camera will give you the upper hand when breaching a door, so you know the enemy positions before entering the room, and your squad will know where to aim beforehand. In other situations, using the spy camera is not the best option, because there might only be a small hallway on the other side of the door, and checking first might slow you down, as you are racing the clock. Most missions will have an objective time goal, which you must beat to get the maximum amount of points, so completing the mission in a quick, clean manner is the optimal goal.Now, twenty dollars might seem like a hefty price for a game like this, but there are three main campaigns, each with at least an hour or more in them, and a ton of single missions, mostly involving just clearing a compound of bad guys. The Steam Workshop offers many player-made campaigns, many of which are very well-made and add many hours of playtime to this game. In my opinion, $20 is a worthy price for this game, but if this isn't at the top of your wishlist, I would reccomend buying it when it goes on sale.

content:
6, 2015
												Reminds me of Frozen Synapse, which is an excellent game, with the exception that you can pause at any time, or you can choose not to pause ever and just guide your troops in real time. The more difficult missions are like puzzles where you have to manage your limited number of team members but still cover all the possible angles where an enemy might try to take you by surprise. You may also have an additional requirement besides just neutralizing all the enemies ("tangos"), such as saving all the hostages. The situation might be that the enemies will start shooting the hostages in one minute, and you must make your way to them quickly enough, or there might be a time bomb to defuse. On some levels you get sniper support, with the sniper somewhere off the screen, able to shoot any enemy that happens to, say, stand in front of a right (or wrong, for him) window. The game also gives you star ratings for each level, and there are additional achievements, such as completing a level with a single trooper, so I find the replay value is very good. Recommended!

Why on earth can't the guys duck under window so they would not be seen.2) No controll on who shoots who. In hostage rescue missions I attack the room from both sides and my guys don't care that there is hostage between you and the bad guy.3) Also the AI is stupid and way too predictable (no fleeing, no surrendering). I accidentally threw flashbang outside a room where hostages are being held. Instead of shooting the hostage some bad guys just ran out of the room so I could easily kill them.... why thank you, but not realistic behavor.Overall it is a nice game.

content:
er 19, 2014
												A fantastic squad-based shooter. I played both this and Breach and Clear in close proximity to one another and love the flexibility Door Kickers in how you play it - you can play it as nearly a RTS and give commands on the fly (though you can't give commands to bulk groups of folks) or you can draft a single plan for the entire mission for all of your troopers - complete with commands to synchronize actions - or anywhere in between (I tend to plot out the first room or two and then react dynamically to whatever is happening by pausing and drawing up new plans for the next few seconds).Cons - you do tend to see the same layouts over and over again - even with random missions, troopers aren't radically different from one another in their personalities.I also wish that there was some form of negotiation option to try to talk to folks while also inserting your SWAT team and performing recon or stealth takedowns - something approaching aspects of SWAT 2 with occasional non-violent resolutions. I do wish that more missions featured 4 man teams.Great tactical game and an absolute blast. Very much recommend this title.

content:
y 13, 2015
												    Door Kickers. Tactical, top down simulation game in which you are in full control of a highly trained SWAT team. Oh yeah, it's brilliant.    The objectives are usually very straight-forward: eliminate all hostiles (or tangos, as they call them), save the captives and/or apprehend the suspects(s). However, every level offers a new location, with unpredictable enemy spawns and new tactics to be developed. Over time and the completion of missions four new classes will be unlocked: Pointman (the starter  class), Assualter (essentially a Pointman with an assualt rifle), Shield (carries a tactical shield which takes most damage), Breacher (shotgun wielding units for close quarters combat and making dramatic entrances) and Stealth (probably the most dynamic, effective classes, although more difficult to design practical tactics for). Stars earned in finishing levels quickly and with minimal casualties can be spent on new weapons and tools.     The main thing to know is the freedom that this game offers. There are so many ways to fulfil objectives that it is unlikely that in a group of 100 people (maybe even more), one person will use the same tactics and methods of completing the mission. You can choose what units you use, where to put them, where to move them from there, how to enter a building, when to enter a building, and many more.     There are, however, a few cons to this game. For instance, it is very common for the game to quit responding while launching for the first time in a while. After quiting and relaunching all is normally resolved, though it is worth mentioning. Also, unit control occasionally will act up, allowing me to only control one officer at once. A simple quit of the level will normally fix the issue though. I am fully aware of how unimportant these are, and in turn will note these are not significant enough to be a reason to not purchase the game.    All in all, Door Kickers is a marvelous example of how games of the genre should be, and deserves more attention. I would give it 9/10. Well done, Killhouse.

er 23, 2014
												Really nice squad level pause-enabled RTS with a SWAT theme. I've played both this and Breach and Clear and like both but Door Kickers gives you a little more control over precision operations. Think of a top-down Rainbow Six, with role-playing game elements too. Very addicting for those interested in this type of game, and with lots to do: plenty of single missions with achievements, several campaigns, a random scenario generator, and a map maker. There are already many user-made contributions to the community. The developer really seems to enjoy working on this game and there is what seems to be pretty good involvement on their site's bulletin board. This game is a steal on sale and bargain even at regular price.

												Impressevly good tactical strategy. Last time I was so exited by tactial game in 2005, it was SWAT4. Door Kickers is something middle of SWAT4 and Frozen Synapse. Before the mission you picking troopers and gear like it was in SWAT4, and mission gameplay is very similar to Frozen Synapse, but here you can set pause whenever you want.The game has a lot of content: 5 classes of troopers, lots of unlockable guns, 3 branches in perks tree, 5 campains, more then 80 single missions, level editor and level generator(!). If it's not enough for you, visit Steam Workshop, there are a lot of extra content created by community. As I can see the game is fully moddable - guns mods, realism mods and visual mods are available.Game control is very tabletishh, but as i can see there is no tablet version of this game. Another bad thing is that Door Kickers is single player game only, but as written in description of the game - "(but MP might come later)".4/5

content:
13, 2016
Rank: 7.5/10Recommendation(s): Be roughly familiar with firearms terminology.Major Theme: Well constructed, UGC friendly, top down tactics shooter.Bought at Price: $5.50 (Steam Sale)I quite enjoyed this game, but I certainly wouldn’t place it into the “must play” or “should play” for most people.


Door Kickers 
A Screenshot of Door Kickers
By: DarK_St3alth




If you are not familiar with some of the firearms terminology used extensively throughout the game, you will find that things don’t make sense. One such example is level III vs. IIIA armor. There’s a wide selection of gear to pick from (a surprise in such games), and purely picking based on stats and names will lend you a bad time.That being said, 12 hours of gameplay certainly gets across the point of the game, and that’s where you should find yourself with a complete campaign, and all the weapons you want unlocked.


Door Kickers 
A Screenshot of Door Kickers
By: DarK_St3alth




Unlocks in this game are very much like other games in this genre, where points/stars from mission ratings allow you to unlock gear and weapons. If you end up doing poorly, you will obviously receive fewer stars and thus less gear and weapons.Levels and campaigns are unique and interesting – but just as in Breach & Clear – the maps could do with more dynamic elements to them. Perhaps this will be explored in Door Kickers 2?


Door Kickers 
A Screenshot of Door Kickers
By: DarK_St3alth




To tide players over until the release of the next game, Door Kickers extensively supports user generated content (UGC), where you can add more maps, UI changes, and core gameplay changes as well. The level editor could have used more polish, but certainly does get the job done.Just recently I have noticed stuttering in my game for a few seconds here and there. I haven’t been able to track down the source of this, but it’s manageable. Your experience will most likely be different in this regard.If you are in a tussle in choosing between Door Kickers and Breach & Clear, I would recommend Door Kickers. You can see my review on the other game, as well as note the large difference in playtime I have.

y 21, 2016
												I like what this game going for.  However, I have several problems with this game.Editing paths when making a plan  is a hassle.  I wish it was something I can overlook but since it's the main tool to use in the game,  I can't.  It's not efficient so you have to workaround the problems with UI. I really hope they clean this up with door kickers 2, if not then I'll be pretty disappointed with that game.  I don't think this game would have such positive reviews if everyone had to finish the missions without pausing since the there are several issues with UI.I like how the AI reacts to your actions such as busting down a door.  I'm not too fond of them being able to spawn in random/different locations.  The reason for this is because it can be tedious coming up with a solid plan as editing paths are a pain. If they imrpove the UI in door kickers 2 then I wouldn't mind random spawns for enemies.  You may find several problems with your plan if it involves flashbangs.   Switching between pause and real time sort of eliminates some of the problems that come up when making a plan.   It's cool in a way, I'm glad it's there, but then it's not really challenging.  $15 would be a more appropriate price tag in my opinion.  BUGS:An obnoxious buzzing sound that won't go away happens often when loading a new level.  Usually, it goes away when you restart so it's not a big issue.  But I saw iron man mode? that you can enable and I believe it mentioned something about not being allowed to restart missions.  I don't know if it causes a problem there.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
, 2016
Door KickersI picked up Door Kickers during the summer sale, planning on spending some time in it while I was stuck using a laptop out of state. I was pleasantly surprised in many ways, and while this title does have a few setbacks it is a fairly fun indie title that I can't help but praise.GraphicsDoor Kickers is a top-down 2D tactics game, meaning I will critique it less for level of detail and more for art-style and consistency. The official content is appealing to look at, though a SWAT team wearing tan uniforms is an odd sight. Community-created content varies, but in general the game looks fairly decent. My primary complaint is that textures will become blurry as you zoom in. You'll also notice that the enemies you face will regularly use the same sprites, and that levels reuse quite a few assets between each-other.


Kicking Doors and Taking Names 
A Screenshot of Door Kickers
By: Lavernius Regalis




AudioThis game features fairly decent audio design, but my main complaint is how repetitive the ambient sounds are. You'll start hearing the same voices on TVs and radios, and the same shouts emanating from mooks before they are helplessly gunned down by your troops. Eventually, you'll find yourself repeating the TV announcers in your head, staying a second ahead of their words. I will complement game for its soundtrack, though; it works well, is pleasant to listen to, and suits the style/setting of Door Kickers.PerformanceThis game performs very well on virtually any system, due to its 2D sprite-based nature. No issues there, as I would've hoped.GameplayDoor Kickers revolves around planning out an entry route for a SWAT team in various situations, where your primary goal is typically to eliminate all hostiles and possibly defuse a bomb in the process. It is fast-paced, unforgiving, and fun to play. However, there are a few faults with it. The unlock system prevents you from accessing very interesting content such as the Stealth class until after you've spent multiple hours in-game, and the planning system seems to be developed with touchscreens in mind, which makes the process of modifying orders that have already been created very difficult at best. Despite this, I still found that it was fun enough to last for quite a few hours, and I still haven't finished even a third of the game's content.


Aircraft Entry 101 
A Screenshot of Door Kickers
By: Lavernius Regalis




Community ContentDoor Kickers does well in this regard, featuring a built-in mod menu and map/mission editor. It doesn't allow for extensive feature modification, but new weapons, armor, maps, and enemies can be created with ease, and existing ones can be modified to your heart's content. I definitely approve of the game's position here.VerdictDoor Kickers is a very fun indie title to waste some time on, thanks to its light weight, fast-paced yet tactical gameplay which is sure to appeal to fans of Rainbow Six or Ghost Recon. However, I don't believe its production value is quite high enough to justify a purchase at full price. It's definitely fun, but it isn't quite $19.99 wholesale fun. I will be keeping my eye on the development of its sequel, 'Door Kickers 2 - Task Force North', however, as that title looks like it will have considerably higher production value and quality.I would recommend Door Kickers, but would suggest waiting for a sale.

content:
r 1, 2015
												Door Kickers is a top-down real-time tactical shooter (shooter in leiu of a more appropriate term - the shooting is automatic and your buds are very competent at running and gunning) in which the player controls a team of SWAT (?) (Armed police, S.T.A.R.S., whatevs) operators tasked with completing an objective at a given location.The objectives typically take the form of a. Kill all the bad guys, b. Arrest a certain specific badguy, or c. Rescue a bunch of helpless hostages.  In most cases objectives of the B & C variety can be over-ruled by killing all the bad guys anyway.During each mission, your task is to choose and path your operators through the building/mission-zone.  This involves selecting means of entry, equipping your team with the correct weapons and breach equipment and otherwise generally co-ordinating your buds so they can support each other by fire, hold down certain angles, throw flashbangs and grenades and escort hostages.The over-world gameplay takes the form of a squad roster in which you may allocate each operator to a specific skill class alongside individual stats and some (seemingly inexhaustible) operator avatars.  From here the player can choose to play a single mission, to gain star economy for in-game upgrades, or embark on a longer campaign - a series of missions which, perhaps with the exception of the first, are enormously expansive and super intricate.Gameplay is nice, ergonomic and smooth and for the vast majority entirely mouse driven.  Though played in real time, the mechanics hinge a lot on the ability to pause and re-plot paths for your dudes.  Cheevos await anyone who can execute an entire mission from a single plot-line before the mission.I have only two gripes about the game really. First, the throwing of flashbangs or other grenades through closed doors is somewhat sluggish and counter-intuitive.  Often, though you've set him to peek the door after he throw's the grenade, your trooper will sit idly taking bullets to his non-mobile ♥♥♥.Secondly, and perhaps minorly, I would love to be able to export my ossom mission completion playthroughs but this function while tantalising me constantly, is not available on Mac.  Devs, plz fix.These tiny gripes aside, Door Kickers is a fantastically gripping game with a well thought out single player campaign.  The weapons and equipment are good in vanilla and, I must say, enhanced tenfold by Gunworld's IoV - Instruments of Violence item pack.Excellent game.  You'll be engaged for hours.

								"If you are considering a tactical squad based shooter to go in your steam list, this is the best I've seen in a while."well, I've been a fan of early access for a while to my detrement. I like the system of replaying a game because it updated i guess, but this game is a hidden gem in a pile of coal. the way they made and make this game allows for easy to play hard to master and really makes you plan before attacking instead of just charging in. While playing i kept finishing a mission then watching the replay of the game just to see how i could've tightened up my movement, get more efficient kills and and avoid making mistakes I made before. For example; I played a garage map, and I breached this one room to stun and rush the enemy down, I ignored the bathroom assuming it was empty and it appears there was one terrorist in the room that walked out and killed one of my guys.However this game does have some downfalls. I feel the developers planned, and probably still plan to, get the player to attach to certain characters and troops. Sadly, I don't get that from this game. The gear also seems quite one sided, having your breachers to equip semi-auto shotguns because its more efficient and equipping the stronger gear so that you have less chance of failure. Perhaps a technology tree so that you can move to those stronger weapons would help, or just balancing the guns all out.Aside the problems I do like this game enough to follow through the development and play i every update so i don't miss anything, I really like what they've done already and the future plans sounds fantastic. If you are considering a tactical squad based shooter to go in your steam list, this is the best I've seen in a while.8/10

												This gamme is a game that I personally have been following since the very earliest of early access for it. This game is a fantastic 2D swat strategy game. You go into a mission, observe your environment, see what soldiers should be sent in and at what locations they should be sent in at. This game requires though to complete the variety of mission types with maximum efficiency. This game has given me hours of fun and frustation in equal amounts. This game constantly provides me with the thrill of split second decisions that could save a man or cause them all to die. Now that this game is officially out it has all the features that I myself have been waiting for, this includes multiple campaigns, troop customisation, leveling your squads, a random mission generator, and hours of enjoyment as you hone yours and your soldiers abilities. Overall I feel this game is worth every penny.

content:
5, 2015
												In Door Kickers, you take control of a SWAT team in a variety of different hostile situations. It is a top down, 2D realtime strategy game that allows you to make critical decisions at a moment's notice or plan entire missions from the very beginning of an operation. After a few hours of playing the Single Missions, I fell in love with Door Kickers. The controls are simple and easy to understand, and watching your plans in action is always satisfying. The sheer amount of different scenarios, ranging from hostage situations to raiding criminal headquarters, makes each mission feel like a new tactical challenge for your SWAT team. With 6 campaigns, 70+ Official Single Missons, Level Generator, unlockable gear, and downloadable mods, Door Kickers has plenty of content to keep you busy.Although I enjoyed Door Kickers, there are a few minor flaws. The game offers you dozens of unlockable gear such as guns and equipment, but I found myself using what I was comfortable with and had no trouble throughout the game. My only incentive to unlock and test all the guns was for the achievement. Also, there were a few situations in the Single Missions and Campaign that feel unbalanced and in favor of the AI.Overall, Door Kickers was an addicting and enjoyable strategy game from start to finish.

content:
1, 2015
												Great tactical game. Takes a bit to get used to the UI but it works well once learned, it's not a standard rip-off of the Starcraft of C&C interface and this is why people might have a bit of a learning curve before you can get into the gameplay. It only took my an hour to get almost everything memorized, not that bad. This game has random maps, pre-made single maps and campaigns. Going through the single maps alone would take a long long time. Campaigns can take a while especially if you have to restart some particularly overly hard missions. Once you play all those most games would be done and become boring, right? Luckily there is a random map generator. You can set size and enemy parameters, and since you don't know exactly what you are going to run in to it ends up being fun for long periods. Even if I have 5 minutes I can run one or two random killhouse maps. Or if I want to spend 3 hours playing a tactical game I can and it still doesn't get dull.Tactically there are various ways to overcome each scenario. You can lockpick a locked door or break it down, or you can use special tools to lockpick it faster or break it faster but these tools take up an inventory slot and are heavier. Or you could use a breacher with a shotgun, but that shotgun becomes the primary weapon and is only useful at short range. There is a give and take to each option and all are viable pending your playstyle and how you want to approach that whole level. And this is just locked doors. The constant variation in the maps and multiple ways to approach each type of situation keeps it varied. Some maps you cannot flank the armored guy and have to face him head on, if you do not have the right equipment you will likely suffer. Sometimes there are too many rooms to flashbang each one so you have to adapt to opening doors and clearing rooms in a different way sweeping around the corner from a wider angle. The game doesn't feel dull even after a long time playing. Gameplay is top-notch and the devs plan on adding to it with co-op and multiplayer eventually. This game has longevity, it hasn't gotten dull yet and I have plenty of hours in it already. It can be played in short spurts or long sessions without an issue. It's a tactical game that requires some thinking. Controls are more than functional and become natural to use with a little bit of time in the game to do exactly what you want down to smaller details like how you want to walk around a corner with a sweeping curve instead of walking straight in. There are various classes that all play differently and can change your play style immensely from one map to another depending on team loadout. You can respec your doctrine points aka skills and you can change classes freely any time you want. I have nothing but good things to say about this game so yes I recommend it. It has been on sale a few times but even full price this is a good one to pick up.
